title: 5 Things We Have Forgotten About Open Source (2014)
The CacheRevolt Manifesto
description:
Seems open-source falls into 5 not-so-fantastic buckets:

  1. Raises millions. Backed by a startup, tends to have Enterprise closed tiers. Company has all the upside, community gets the crumbs.
  2. Has millions or billions. Backed by a big player, incentivized to “dual-license” or use proprietary licenses. Think IBM RHEL or Snap’s KeyDB. Company laughs all the way to the bank, or only in a matter of time…
  3. Zero dollars. Essentially, “in-house”. At the mercy of the employer, unless the maintainer rage-quits for greener pastures. Company has all the upside, maintainer gets a pat on the back.
  4. A few bucks. Copy-left, mostly. Bootstrap and offer enterprise support or long-term contracts. Pays less than flipping burgers, and no other contributors benefit. There’s no real upside, except for the companies.
  5. A few pennies. Apply for grants. Shake a tin cup. Maybe hire a developer or two, making you the top 0.1% of open source. Still broke, but hey, at least you’re not alone!

The CacheRevolt Manifesto explores a new approach to open-source funding, aiming to align corporate interests with the community. Putting the maintainers and core contributors in the driver’s seat by tying voting rights to stock ownership in a fictitious corporation. And they are legally obligated to produce permissively licensed software. This satirical take on open-source governance raises important questions about sustainability and the future of critical projects.

This model also levels the playing field, as big companies would need to buy out smaller shareholders to gain significant influence.

title: Who will build new search engines for new personal AI agents?
Linux (desktop) troubleshooting techniques and resources?
description:
I’ve used Linux my whole life, but I’m still not very good at troubleshooting and recovering from system freezes, distro-specific bugs, and quirks with drivers and suspend.

I know some of the basic stuff — Magic SysRq keys (REISUB), dropping to a virtual terminal with Ctrl+Alt+F3, killing processes if it’s an app that’s frozen, grepping dmesg, and purging and re-installing graphics drivers. But I haven’t found any pragmatic, in-depth guides on more intermediate-level Linux troubleshooting.

Are there any resources you’d recommend?

What are your go-to techniques for effectively troubleshooting issues with Linux (desktop) systems?

Thanks!
